body:
Hi Artur,

thanks for making the changes.
But creating a Map of category to a List of items seem to duplicate and waste storage space. Possible to store the item category for each item instead?
instead of,

``` scala
val categoryItemsMap: Map[String, Set[Int]])
```

use something like:

``` scala
case class Item(categories: Option[List[String]])

val items: Map[Int, Item]
```

Then in predict(), find out list of item that belong to the categories in query.

How do you think?

Thanks
Kenneth

Hi Kenneth,

I've computed the storage and time cost for both alternatives and I've come up with the following:

**Current approach**
- Storage: There is a `Map` for each different category, plus an `Int` for each match between a category and an item. Total: `O(categories + items * average(categories per item) * size(Int))`
- Time: There's a set lookup (effectively constant time) for each considered item and for each queried category. Total: `O(considered items * queried categories)`

**Alternative approach**
- Storage: There is an `Item` and a `List` object for each item, plus a `String` for each match between a category and an item. Total: `O(items + items * average(categories per item) * size(String))`  
- Time: For each considered item, there's a check between each of the item categories and each of the query categories. Total: `O(considered items * average(categories per item) * queried categories)`

The storage cost in the alternative approach would be a bit higher, since a `String` takes more space than an `Int`. This could be solved by mapping category `String`s to `Int`s as it's done for user and item ids. The number of items is probably going to be in general higher than the number of categories, but this part of the expression is not going to dominate except in very sparse sets of data.

Regarding time, the alternative approach would also be a bit more costly, but this could also be solved by substituting the `List` of categories by a `Set` of categories.

With these two optimizations, both storage and time cost would be equivalent between the two alternatives. 

I've thought about another possible storage optimization, which would not help in the asymptotic case but would probably help in most real-life cases. That would be, in the alternative approach, to try to have the JVM reuse the `List` or `Set` of item categories where two items have the same set of categories. E.g., if there are two films that are both "action" and "adventure", in the naive implementation there would be 2 `List("action", "adventure")` objects (with the possible `Set` and `Int` variants), while we could detect those cases and reuse a single object. Testing on the 100k MovieLens data, from 1682 total items there are only 216 different sets of categories. In other domains with more categories, though, the benefits of this approach would be less.

Please let me know which variation do you prefer to have implemented.

Kind regards,
Artur
Thanks!
Thanks for updating the examples!

Hi Artur,

Great analysis and agree with you!
Let's keep your current implementation.

Hi Maxim,

Thanks!
- Which template and which version is your modification based on? Would you update README about this?
- The Serving has code for combining multiple algorithm's PredictedResult. For simplicity and the purpose of this example, i think better to make the Serving simple as original (such as https://github.com/PredictionIO/template-scala-parallel-recommendation/blob/v0.1.2/src/main/scala/Serving.scala). so that it won't confuse user that the Serving change is needed for this.
- There is a Scala import program inside src/. Do you think it's cleaner if make it a separate project in another directory (say, a data/ directory ) so that not mixing with the engine source code ? And would you update REAMDE to teach user how to run the import program too.

Thanks
Kenneth
Compatible with Elasticsearch 1.3 as a meta data store. Merging. Thanks!

Hi Kenneth,

Thanks for your comments, i have simplified the Serving. 
I have moved data import script under `./data` in the example.
I have also updated `README.md` with instructions on how to use the import command line tool and pointed template version that i was based on. 
Let me know if there's any other things i should improve.

Thanks
Maxim.

Hi Maxim,

Thanks for the updates. Nice work!
- Could you describe a bit about what and why Serving is modified in README as well?
  (e.g re-sort item based on the year?).
- In Serving, is there any reason that you do groupBy item id and sum the scores (i thought the result.itemScores should contain top unique items already?)

``` scala
result.itemScores
        .groupBy(_.item)
        .mapValues { itemScores ⇒
          itemScores.map(_.score).reduce(_ + _) ...
```

Thanks
Kenneth

Kenneth,

excess grouping code was accidentally left after Serving simplifying. Sorry for that, my bad. It is fixed now. I have added actual recommendation result filtering as a `bonus` like Hagay Gazuli mentioned in the [google group](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/predictionio-user/created$20%7Csort:date/predictionio-user/LEHxuc0Bu_0/W9RkAApvivsJ)

Thanks! That's very useful.

Largely historical. `$HBASE_CONF_DIR` set to `$PIO_HOME/conf` has been around since the beginning of 0.8, and is included in the JVM classpath for the storage layer's HBase client. This is why it seems incomplete, as only the quorum configuration is required if you have a setup connecting to a remote HBase cluster.

`$PIO_STORAGE_SOURCES_HBASE_HOME` was recently added for the `bin/pio-start-all` script. Agree that `HBASE_CONF_DIR` can be derived from that variable if we always require `$PIO_STORAGE_SOURCES_HBASE_HOME` to be set. `bin/pio-start-all`, however, is designed for quick-and-dirty standalone setups, so `$PIO_STORAGE_SOURCES_HBASE_HOME` does not necessary need to exist for distributed setups. Despite the fact that they serve different purposes, I agree that the current documentation is not clear and makes them kind of confusing.

So in summary, the current situation is due to some hacking to handle all of the following cases:
- PIO with remote HBase
- PIO with bundled local HBase
- PIO with non-bundled local HBase

I do not have a better solution at the code level at the moment, besides improving the documentation. Any suggestion is welcome.

Thanks for the PR! Merging the docs now.

Yes they do work for more standard or networked HBase. However I'd suggest that PIO have only environment variable pointing to hbase (though the name is somewhat verbose and confusing Maybe just PIO_HBASE_HOME=)

```
PIO_STORAGE_SOURCES_HBASE_HOME=/path/to/hbase
```

inside of the hbase dir you'll find "conf" for all three cases. This may mean changing your job/driver code but will rationalize the hbase conf to be the same for all cases; "edit in your hbase/conf/hbase-site.xml" This will handle all your situations
- PIO with remote HBase
- PIO with bundled local HBase
- PIO with non-bundled local HBase

Further it will allow users to follow the HBase instructions and tutorials verbatim.
Actually the basis of the suggestion is to remove hbase-site.xml from pio/conf and leave it with hbase/conf
Thanks @detrevid ! Looking good. Would you mind adding a line in NOTICE.txt to credit https://github.com/magro/kryo-serializers please? This is a requirement of APL2.

Agree that `conf/hbase-site.xml` has been causing some confusion with our team as well. Also, apparently HBase is using `$HBASE_CONF_DIR` as well so changing it to other values, and then calling `start-hbase.sh` inside `pio-start-all` will screw things up.

For the remote HBase case, I think it is categorized as advanced usage and some documentation should clear it up.
Done
Thanks!

That was fast! Thanks for creating the ticket. I didn't know it was that simple >.<

I tried to reuse the single event creation code but the return types are different so I was stuck. For single event, the completion handler returns `(status, Map("message": "..."))` while each event in the batch request returns `Map("status": 400, "message": "...")`. Do you have any tips on how to refactor this?

Btw, should I update the documentation page to reflect this support for batch requests?
Thanks!
Thanks!
Thanks!
Looks like this creates a new REST endpoint? is there a reason to not include this in any event? So any event can have either a single object or array of objects?

Yes, this creates a new REST endpoint. We could handle both batch and single event requests at the same end point but in that case, both the client and the server handler need to do extra checking to know  what type of request/response it is dealing with. Because the format for batch requests and responses are quite different from those of single event (e.g. failure of creating some single event in a batch request will not response with an error code unlike a single request), I think it is better to separate them.

But why would you not respond with an error if one of the batch failed? The use case I have in mind is where many events are created with a single user action. This shouldn't require many events to be sent separately so if we use the batch endpoint we would never know when a failure happened.

Ideally the client should get an error so they can retry, right? It might not be usable without the error return for my usecase.

Also the format should be a json event or a json array of events, right? This seems easy to check for in a single endpoint, where array = batch, single = one event.

We could have them use the batch endpoint always, creating an array of one or more events with each request but we would need the error as much for batch as for single requests.

For batch request, the response's status code is meant for system failure (e.g. server down or database connection error). Even if we return an global error code when a single event failed to create, we still have to go through all events to check which exact event fails in order to retry. So in batch request, each event will have its corresponding status code in the response's body (please see the sample response in the doc).

> Also the format should be a json event or a json array of events, right? This seems easy to check for in a single endpoint, where array = batch, single = one event.

Yes, this is true. The server can check the request format to see if it is a batch or single request. But then the client also has to check the response format to determine if it is handling a batch or single request. I think this creates unnecessary work. Of course, one can always send a batch request with only 1 event though.
ok this looks good to me. The errors reported from the endpoint are better than I'd expect. Several of our users will probably use this endpoint exclusively so I can't wait to try it, Thanks Minh!

@dszeto is the KryoInstantiator a non-core Kryo add-on? Don't know Kryo well enough but since it's at the core of a lot of very hard to find errors I try to avoid touching it and using Scala/Java serialization even though it may be slightly slower. Do we have a POV on mucking with Kryo? Should this be merged?
